description: From Middle English afore, aforn, from Old English onforan or ætforan; equivalent to a- +‎ fore.

entries.meaning: (nautical) In the fore part of a ship.
Before; in advance of the time of.
examples: He said he was jealous, and craved something to ease his care. 'It's but a small thing I ask,' says he, 'but it will make me a happy man, and nothing ever shall come atween us. Tryst wi' me for Beltane's E'en on the Sker sands, at the green link o' the burn where the sands begin, on the ebb o' the tide when midnight is by, but afore cockcrow. For,' said he, 'that was our forbears' tryst for true lovers, and wherefore no for you and me?'

entries.meaning: Before; situated geographically or metaphorically in front of.
